23. Money Financed Government Deficits and Price Levels

23.1Overview¶

This lecture extends and modifies the model in this lecture A Monetarist Theory of Price Levels by modifying the law of motion that governed the supply of money.

The model in this lecture consists of two components

  • a demand function for money

  • a law of motion for the supply of money

The demand function describes the public’s demand for “real balances”, defined as the ratio of nominal money balances to the price level

  • it assumes that the demand for real balance today varies inversely with the rate of inflation that the public forecasts to prevail between today and tomorrow

  • it assumes that the public’s forecast of that rate of inflation is perfect

The law of motion for the supply of money assumes that the government prints money to finance government expenditures

Our model equates the demand for money to the supply at each time t≥0t \geq 0t≥0.

Equality between those demands and supply gives a dynamic model in which money supply and price level sequences are simultaneously determined by a set of simultaneous linear equations.

These equations take the form of what is often called vector linear difference equations.

In this lecture, we’ll roll up our sleeves and solve those equations in two different ways.

(One of the methods for solving vector linear difference equations will take advantage of a decomposition of a matrix that is studied in this lecture Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors.)

In this lecture we will encounter these concepts from macroeconomics:

  • an inflation tax that a government gathers by printing paper or electronic money

  • a dynamic Laffer curve in the inflation tax rate that has two stationary equilibria

  • perverse dynamics under rational expectations in which the system converges to the higher stationary inflation tax rate

  • a peculiar comparative stationary-state outcome connected with that stationary inflation rate: it asserts that inflation can be reduced by running higher government deficits, i.e., by raising more resources by printing money.

The same qualitative outcomes prevail in this lecture Inflation Rate Laffer Curves that studies a nonlinear version of the model in this lecture.

These outcomes set the stage for the analysis to be presented in this lecture Laffer Curves with Adaptive Expectations that studies a nonlinear version of the present model; it assumes a version of “adaptive expectations” instead of rational expectations.

That lecture will show that

  • replacing rational expectations with adaptive expectations leaves the two stationary inflation rates unchanged, but that …\ldots…

  • it reverses the perverse dynamics by making the lower stationary inflation rate the one to which the system typically converges

  • a more plausible comparative dynamic outcome emerges in which now inflation can be reduced by running lower government deficits

This outcome will be used to justify a selection of a stationary inflation rate that underlies the analysis of unpleasant monetarist arithmetic to be studied in this lecture Some Unpleasant Monetarist Arithmetic.

We’ll use these tools from linear algebra:

  • matrix multiplication

  • matrix inversion

  • eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix

23.2Demand for and supply of money¶

We say demands and supplies (plurals) because there is one of each for each t≥0t \geq 0t≥0.

Let

  • mt+1m_{t+1}mt+1​ be the supply of currency at the end of time t≥0t \geq 0t≥0

  • mtm_{t}mt​ be the supply of currency brought into time ttt from time t−1t-1t−1

  • ggg be the government deficit that is financed by printing currency at t≥1t \geq 1t≥1

  • mt+1dm_{t+1}^dmt+1d​ be the demand at time ttt for currency to bring into time t+1t+1t+1

  • ptp_tpt​ be the price level at time ttt

  • bt=mt+1ptb_t = \frac{m_{t+1}}{p_t}bt​=pt​mt+1​​ is real balances at the end of time ttt

  • Rt=ptpt+1R_t = \frac{p_t}{p_{t+1}} Rt​=pt+1​pt​​ be the gross rate of return on currency held from time ttt to time t+1t+1t+1

It is often helpful to state units in which quantities are measured:

  • mtm_tmt​ and mtdm_t^dmtd​ are measured in dollars

  • ggg is measured in time ttt goods

  • ptp_tpt​ is measured in dollars per time ttt goods

  • RtR_tRt​ is measured in time t+1t+1t+1 goods per unit of time ttt goods

  • btb_tbt​ is measured in time ttt goods

Our job now is to specify demand and supply functions for money.

We assume that the demand for currency satisfies the Cagan-like demand function

mt+1dpt=γ1−γ2pt+1pt,t≥0\frac{m_{t+1}^d}{p_t}=\gamma_1 - \gamma_2 \frac{p_{t+1}}{p_t}, \quad t \geq 0pt​mt+1d​​=γ1​−γ2​pt​pt+1​​,t≥0
(1)

where γ1,γ2\gamma_1, \gamma_2γ1​,γ2​ are positive parameters.

Now we turn to the supply of money.

We assume that m0>0m_0 >0m0​>0 is an “initial condition” determined outside the model.

We set m0m_0m0​ at some arbitrary positive value, say $100.

For t≥1 t \geq 1t≥1, we assume that the supply of money is determined by the government’s budget constraint

mt+1−mt=ptg,t≥0m_{t+1} - m_{t} = p_t g , \quad t \geq 0mt+1​−mt​=pt​g,t≥0
(2)

According to this equation, each period, the government prints money to pay for quantity ggg of goods.

In an equilibrium, the demand for currency equals the supply:

mt+1d=mt+1,t≥0m_{t+1}^d = m_{t+1}, \quad t \geq 0mt+1d​=mt+1​,t≥0
(3)

Let’s take a moment to think about what equation (3) tells us.

The demand for money at any time ttt depends on the price level at time ttt and the price level at time t+1t+1t+1.

The supply of money at time t+1t+1t+1 depends on the money supply at time ttt and the price level at time ttt.

So the infinite sequence of equations (3) for t≥0 t \geq 0t≥0 imply that the sequences {pt}t=0∞\{p_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{pt​}t=0∞​ and {mt}t=0∞\{m_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{mt​}t=0∞​ are tied together and ultimately simulataneously determined.

23.3Equilibrium price and money supply sequences¶

The preceding specifications imply that for t≥1t \geq 1t≥1, real balances evolve according to

mt+1pt−mtpt−1pt−1pt=g\frac{m_{t+1}}{p_t} - \frac{m_{t}}{p_{t-1}} \frac{p_{t-1}}{p_t} = gpt​mt+1​​−pt−1​mt​​pt​pt−1​​=g
(4)

or

bt−bt−1Rt−1=gb_t - b_{t-1} R_{t-1} = gbt​−bt−1​Rt−1​=g
(5)

The demand for real balances is

bt=γ1−γ2Rt−1.b_t = \gamma_1 - \gamma_2 R_t^{-1} .bt​=γ1​−γ2​Rt−1​.
(6)

We’ll restrict our attention to parameter values and associated gross real rates of return on real balances that assure that the demand for real balances is positive, which according to (6) means that

bt=γ1−γ2Rt−1>0b_t = \gamma_1 - \gamma_2 R_t^{-1} > 0bt​=γ1​−γ2​Rt−1​>0
(7)

which implies that

Rt≥(γ2γ1)≡R‾R_t \geq \left( \frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1} \right) \equiv \underline RRt​≥(γ1​γ2​​)≡R​
(8)

Gross real rate of return R‾\underline RR​ is the smallest rate of return on currency that is consistent with a nonnegative demand for real balances.

We shall describe two distinct but closely related ways of computing a pair {pt,mt}t=0∞\{p_t, m_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{pt​,mt​}t=0∞​ of sequences for the price level and money supply.

But first it is instructive to describe a special type of equilibrium known as a steady state.

In a steady-state equilibrium, a subset of key variables remain constant or invariant over time, while remaining variables can be expressed as functions of those constant variables.

Finding such state variables is something of an art.

In many models, a good source of candidates for such invariant variables is a set of ratios.

This is true in the present model.

23.3.1Steady states¶

In a steady-state equilibrium of the model we are studying,

Rt=Rˉbt=bˉ\begin{aligned} R_t & = \bar R \cr b_t & = \bar b \end{aligned}Rt​bt​​=Rˉ=bˉ​
(9)

for t≥0t \geq 0t≥0.

Notice that both Rt=ptpt+1R_t = \frac{p_t}{p_{t+1}}Rt​=pt+1​pt​​ and bt=mt+1ptb_t = \frac{m_{t+1}}{p_t} bt​=pt​mt+1​​ are ratios.

To compute a steady state, we seek gross rates of return on currency and real balances Rˉ,bˉ\bar R, \bar bRˉ,bˉ that satisfy steady-state versions of both the government budget constraint and the demand function for real balances:

g=bˉ(1−Rˉ)bˉ=γ1−γ2Rˉ−1\begin{aligned} g & = \bar b ( 1 - \bar R) \cr \bar b & = \gamma_1- \gamma_2 \bar R^{-1} \end{aligned}gbˉ​=bˉ(1−Rˉ)=γ1​−γ2​Rˉ−1​
(10)

Together these equations imply

(γ1+γ2)−γ2Rˉ−γ1Rˉ=g(\gamma_1 + \gamma_2) - \frac{\gamma_2}{\bar R} - \gamma_1 \bar R = g(γ1​+γ2​)−Rˉγ2​​−γ1​Rˉ=g
(11)

The left side is the steady-state amount of seigniorage or government revenues that the government gathers by paying a gross rate of return Rˉ≤1\bar R \le 1Rˉ≤1 on currency.

The right side is government expenditures.

Define steady-state seigniorage as

S(Rˉ)=(γ1+γ2)−γ2Rˉ−γ1RˉS(\bar R) = (\gamma_1 + \gamma_2) - \frac{\gamma_2}{\bar R} - \gamma_1 \bar RS(Rˉ)=(γ1​+γ2​)−Rˉγ2​​−γ1​Rˉ
(12)

Notice that S(Rˉ)≥0S(\bar R) \geq 0S(Rˉ)≥0 only when Rˉ∈[γ2γ1,1]≡[R‾,R‾]\bar R \in [\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}, 1] \equiv [\underline R, \overline R]Rˉ∈[γ1​γ2​​,1]≡[R​,R] and that S(Rˉ)=0S(\bar R) = 0S(Rˉ)=0 if Rˉ=R‾\bar R = \underline RRˉ=R​ or if Rˉ=R‾\bar R = \overline RRˉ=R.

We shall study equilibrium sequences that satisfy

Rt∈[R‾,R‾],t≥0.R_t \in [\underline R, \overline R], \quad t \geq 0.Rt​∈[R​,R],t≥0.
(13)

Maximizing steady-state seigniorage (12) with respect to Rˉ\bar RRˉ, we find that the maximizing rate of return on currency is

Rˉmax=γ2γ1\bar R_{\rm max} = \sqrt{\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}}Rˉmax​=γ1​γ2​​​
(14)

and that the associated maximum seigniorage revenue that the government can gather from printing money is

(γ1+γ2)−γ2Rˉmax−γ1Rˉmax(\gamma_1 + \gamma_2) - \frac{\gamma_2}{\bar R_{\rm max}} - \gamma_1 \bar R_{\rm max}(γ1​+γ2​)−Rˉmax​γ2​​−γ1​Rˉmax​
(15)

It is useful to rewrite equation (11) as

−γ2+(γ1+γ2−g)Rˉ−γ1Rˉ2=0-\gamma_2 + (\gamma_1 + \gamma_2 - g) \bar R - \gamma_1 \bar R^2 = 0−γ2​+(γ1​+γ2​−g)Rˉ−γ1​Rˉ2=0
(16)

A steady state gross rate of return Rˉ\bar RRˉ solves quadratic equation (16).

So two steady states typically exist.

23.4Some code¶

Let’s start with some imports:

import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
from matplotlib.ticker import MaxNLocator
plt.rcParams['figure.dpi'] = 300
from collections import namedtuple

Let’s set some parameter values and compute possible steady-state rates of return on currency Rˉ\bar RRˉ, the seigniorage maximizing rate of return on currency, and an object that we’ll discuss later, namely, an initial price level p0p_0p0​ associated with the maximum steady-state rate of return on currency.

First, we create a namedtuple to store parameters so that we can reuse this namedtuple in our functions throughout this lecture

# Create a namedtuple that contains parameters
MoneySupplyModel = namedtuple("MoneySupplyModel", 
                        ["γ1", "γ2", "g", 
                         "M0", "R_u", "R_l"])

def create_model(γ1=100, γ2=50, g=3.0, M0=100):
    
    # Calculate the steady states for R
    R_steady = np.roots((-γ1, γ1 + γ2 - g, -γ2))
    R_u, R_l = R_steady
    print("[R_u, R_l] =", R_steady)
    
    return MoneySupplyModel(γ1=γ1, γ2=γ2, g=g, M0=M0, R_u=R_u, R_l=R_l)

Now we compute the Rˉmax\bar R_{\rm max}Rˉmax​ and corresponding revenue

def seign(R, model):
    γ1, γ2, g = model.γ1, model.γ2, model.g
    return -γ2/R + (γ1 + γ2)  - γ1 * R

msm = create_model()

# Calculate initial guess for p0
p0_guess = msm.M0 / (msm.γ1 - msm.g - msm.γ2 / msm.R_u)
print(f'p0 guess = {p0_guess:.4f}')

# Calculate seigniorage maximizing rate of return
R_max = np.sqrt(msm.γ2/msm.γ1)
g_max = seign(R_max, msm)
print(f'R_max, g_max = {R_max:.4f}, {g_max:.4f}')

Now let’s plot seigniorage as a function of alternative potential steady-state values of RRR.

We’ll see that there are two steady-state values of RRR that attain seigniorage levels equal to ggg, one that we’ll denote RℓR_\ellRℓ​, another that we’ll denote RuR_uRu​.

They satisfy Rℓ<RuR_\ell < R_uRℓ​<Ru​ and are affiliated with a higher inflation tax rate (1−Rℓ)(1-R_\ell)(1−Rℓ​) and a lower inflation tax rate 1−Ru1 - R_u1−Ru​.

# Generate values for R
R_values = np.linspace(msm.γ2/msm.γ1, 1, 250)

# Calculate the function values
seign_values = seign(R_values, msm)

# Visualize seign_values against R values
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(11, 5))
plt.plot(R_values, seign_values, label='inflation tax revenue')
plt.axhline(y=msm.g, color='red', linestyle='--', label='government deficit')
plt.xlabel('$R$')
plt.ylabel('seigniorage')

plt.legend()
plt.show()

Let’s print the two steady-state rates of return Rˉ\bar RRˉ and the associated seigniorage revenues that the government collects.

(By construction, both steady-state rates of return should raise the same amounts real revenue.)

We hope that the following code will confirm this.

g1 = seign(msm.R_u, msm)
print(f'R_u, g_u = {msm.R_u:.4f}, {g1:.4f}')

g2 = seign(msm.R_l, msm)
print(f'R_l, g_l = {msm.R_l:.4f}, {g2:.4f}')

Now let’s compute the maximum steady-state amount of seigniorage that could be gathered by printing money and the state-state rate of return on money that attains it.

23.5Two computation strategies¶

We now proceed to compute equilibria, not necessarily steady states.

We shall deploy two distinct computation strategies.

23.5.1Method 1¶

  • set R0∈[γ2γ1,Ru]R_0 \in [\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}, R_u]R0​∈[γ1​γ2​​,Ru​] and compute b0=γ1−γ2/R0b_0 = \gamma_1 - \gamma_2/R_0b0​=γ1​−γ2​/R0​.

  • compute sequences {Rt,bt}t=1∞\{R_t, b_t\}_{t=1}^\infty{Rt​,bt​}t=1∞​ of rates of return and real balances that are associated with an equilibrium by solving equation (5) and (6) sequentially for t≥1t \geq 1t≥1:

bt=bt−1Rt−1+gRt−1=γ1γ2−γ2−1bt\begin{aligned} b_t & = b_{t-1} R_{t-1} + g \cr R_t^{-1} & = \frac{\gamma_1}{\gamma_2} - \gamma_2^{-1} b_t \end{aligned}bt​Rt−1​​=bt−1​Rt−1​+g=γ2​γ1​​−γ2−1​bt​​
(17)

  • Construct the associated equilibrium p0p_0p0​ from

p0=m0γ1−g−γ2/R0p_0 = \frac{m_0}{\gamma_1 - g - \gamma_2/R_0}p0​=γ1​−g−γ2​/R0​m0​​
(18)

  • compute {pt,mt}t=1∞\{p_t, m_t\}_{t=1}^\infty{pt​,mt​}t=1∞​ by solving the following equations sequentially

pt=Rtpt−1mt=bt−1pt\begin{aligned} p_t & = R_t p_{t-1} \cr m_t & = b_{t-1} p_t \end{aligned}pt​mt​​=Rt​pt−1​=bt−1​pt​​
(19)
Remark 1

Method 1 uses an indirect approach to computing an equilibrium by first computing an equilibrium {Rt,bt}t=0∞\{R_t, b_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{Rt​,bt​}t=0∞​ sequence and then using it to back out an equilibrium {pt,mt}t=0∞\{p_t, m_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{pt​,mt​}t=0∞​ sequence.

Remark 2

Notice that method 1 starts by picking an initial condition R0R_0R0​ from a set [γ2γ1,Ru][\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}, R_u][γ1​γ2​​,Ru​]. Equilibrium {pt,mt}t=0∞\{p_t, m_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{pt​,mt​}t=0∞​ sequences are not unique. There is actually a continuum of equilibria indexed by a choice of R0R_0R0​ from the set [γ2γ1,Ru][\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}, R_u][γ1​γ2​​,Ru​].

Remark 3

Associated with each selection of R0R_0R0​ there is a unique p0p_0p0​ described by equation (18).

23.5.2Method 2¶

This method deploys a direct approach. It defines a “state vector” yt=[mtpt]y_t = \begin{bmatrix} m_t \cr p_t\end{bmatrix} yt​=[mt​pt​​] and formulates equilibrium conditions (1), (2), and (3) in terms of a first-order vector difference equation

yt+1=Myt,t≥0,y_{t+1} = M y_t, \quad t \geq 0 ,yt+1​=Myt​,t≥0,
(20)

where we temporarily take y0=[m0p0]y_0 = \begin{bmatrix} m_0 \cr p_0 \end{bmatrix}y0​=[m0​p0​​] as an initial condition.

The solution is

yt=Mty0.y_t = M^t y_0 .yt​=Mty0​.
(21)

Now let’s think about the initial condition y0y_0y0​.

It is natural to take the initial stock of money m0>0m_0 >0m0​>0 as an initial condition.

But what about p0p_0p0​?

Isn’t it something that we want to be determined by our model?

Yes, but sometimes we want too much, because there is actually a continuum of initial p0p_0p0​ levels that are compatible with the existence of an equilibrium.

As we shall see soon, selecting an initial p0p_0p0​ in method 2 is intimately tied to selecting an initial rate of return on currency R0R_0R0​ in method 1.

23.6Computation method 1¶

Remember that there exist two steady-state equilibrium values Rℓ<Ru R_\ell < R_uRℓ​<Ru​ of the rate of return on currency RtR_tRt​.

We proceed as follows.

Start at t=0t=0t=0

  • select a R0∈[γ2γ1,Ru]R_0 \in [\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}, R_u]R0​∈[γ1​γ2​​,Ru​]

  • compute b0=γ1−γ0R0−1b_0 = \gamma_1 - \gamma_0 R_0^{-1} b0​=γ1​−γ0​R0−1​

Then for t≥1t \geq 1t≥1 construct bt,Rtb_t, R_tbt​,Rt​ by iterating on equation (17).

When we implement this part of method 1, we shall discover the following striking outcome:

  • starting from an R0R_0R0​ in [γ2γ1,Ru][\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}, R_u][γ1​γ2​​,Ru​], we shall find that {Rt}\{R_t\}{Rt​} always converges to a limiting “steady state” value Rˉ\bar RRˉ that depends on the initial condition R0R_0R0​.

  • there are only two possible limit points {Rℓ,Ru}\{ R_\ell, R_u\}{Rℓ​,Ru​}.

  • for almost every initial condition R0R_0R0​, lim⁡t→+∞Rt=Rℓ\lim_{t \rightarrow +\infty} R_t = R_\elllimt→+∞​Rt​=Rℓ​.

  • if and only if R0=RuR_0 = R_uR0​=Ru​, lim⁡t→+∞Rt=Ru\lim_{t \rightarrow +\infty} R_t = R_ulimt→+∞​Rt​=Ru​.

The quantity 1−Rt1 - R_t1−Rt​ can be interpreted as an inflation tax rate that the government imposes on holders of its currency.

We shall soon see that the existence of two steady-state rates of return on currency that serve to finance the government deficit of ggg indicates the presence of a Laffer curve in the inflation tax rate.

Note

Arthur Laffer’s curve plots a hump shaped curve of revenue raised from a tax against the tax rate.
Its hump shape indicates that there are typically two tax rates that yield the same amount of revenue. This is due to two countervailing courses, one being that raising a tax rate typically decreases the base of the tax as people take decisions to reduce their exposure to the tax.

def simulate_system(R0, model, num_steps):
    γ1, γ2, g = model.γ1, model.γ2, model.g

    # Initialize arrays to store results
    b_values = np.empty(num_steps)
    R_values = np.empty(num_steps)

    # Initial values
    b_values[0] = γ1 - γ2/R0
    R_values[0] = 1 / (γ1/γ2 - (1 / γ2) * b_values[0])

    # Iterate over time steps
    for t in range(1, num_steps):
        b_t = b_values[t - 1] * R_values[t - 1] + g
        R_values[t] = 1 / (γ1/γ2 - (1/γ2) * b_t)
        b_values[t] = b_t

    return b_values, R_values

Let’s write some code to plot outcomes for several possible initial values R0R_0R0​.

Notebook Cell
line_params = {'lw': 1.5, 
              'marker': 'o',
              'markersize': 3}

def annotate_graph(ax, model, num_steps):
    for y, label in [(model.R_u, '$R_u$'), (model.R_l, '$R_l$'), 
                     (model.γ2 / model.γ1, r'$\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}$')]:
        ax.axhline(y=y, color='grey', linestyle='--', lw=1.5, alpha=0.6)
        ax.text(num_steps * 1.02, y, label, verticalalignment='center', 
                color='grey', size=12)

def draw_paths(R0_values, model, line_params, num_steps):

    fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 1, figsize=(8, 8), sharex=True)
    
    # Pre-compute time steps
    time_steps = np.arange(num_steps) 
    
    # Iterate over R_0s and simulate the system 
    for R0 in R0_values:
        b_values, R_values = simulate_system(R0, model, num_steps)
        
        # Plot R_t against time
        axes[0].plot(time_steps, R_values, **line_params)
        
        # Plot b_t against time
        axes[1].plot(time_steps, b_values, **line_params)
        
    # Add line and text annotations to the subgraph 
    annotate_graph(axes[0], model, num_steps)
    
    # Add Labels
    axes[0].set_ylabel('$R_t$')
    axes[1].set_xlabel('timestep')
    axes[1].set_ylabel('$b_t$')
    axes[1].xaxis.set_major_locator(MaxNLocator(integer=True))
    
    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()

Let’s plot distinct outcomes associated with several R0∈[γ2γ1,Ru]R_0 \in [\frac{\gamma_2}{\gamma_1}, R_u]R0​∈[γ1​γ2​​,Ru​].

Each line below shows a path associated with a different R0R_0R0​.

# Create a grid of R_0s
R0s = np.linspace(msm.γ2/msm.γ1, msm.R_u, 9)
R0s = np.append(msm.R_l, R0s)
draw_paths(R0s, msm, line_params, num_steps=20)

Notice how sequences that start from R0R_0R0​ in the half-open interval [Rℓ,Ru)[R_\ell, R_u)[Rℓ​,Ru​) converge to the steady state associated with to Rℓ R_\ellRℓ​.

23.7Computation method 2¶

Set mt=mtdm_t = m_t^d mt​=mtd​ for all t≥−1t \geq -1t≥−1.

Let

yt=[mtpt].y_t = \begin{bmatrix} m_{t} \cr p_{t} \end{bmatrix} .yt​=[mt​pt​​].
(22)

Represent equilibrium conditions (1), (2), and (3) as

[1γ210][mt+1pt+1]=[0γ11g][mtpt]\begin{bmatrix} 1 & \gamma_2 \cr 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} m_{t+1} \cr p_{t+1} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & \gamma_1 \cr 1 & g \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} m_{t} \cr p_{t} \end{bmatrix}[11​γ2​0​][mt+1​pt+1​​]=[01​γ1​g​][mt​pt​​]
(23)

or

H1yt=H2yt−1H_1 y_t = H_2 y_{t-1}H1​yt​=H2​yt−1​
(24)

where

H1=[1γ210]H2=[0γ11g]\begin{aligned} H_1 & = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & \gamma_2 \cr 1 & 0 \end{bmatrix} \cr H_2 & = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & \gamma_1 \cr 1 & g \end{bmatrix} \end{aligned}H1​H2​​=[11​γ2​0​]=[01​γ1​g​]​
(25)
H1 = np.array([[1, msm.γ2], 
               [1, 0]])
H2 = np.array([[0, msm.γ1], 
               [1, msm.g]])

Define

H=H1−1H2H = H_1^{-1} H_2H=H1−1​H2​
(26)
H = np.linalg.solve(H1, H2)
print('H = \n', H)

and write the system (23) as

yt+1=Hyt,t≥0y_{t+1} = H y_t, \quad t \geq 0yt+1​=Hyt​,t≥0
(27)

so that {yt}t=0\{y_t\}_{t=0}{yt​}t=0​ can be computed from

yt=Hty0,t≥0y_t = H^t y_0, t \geq 0yt​=Hty0​,t≥0
(28)

where

y0=[m0p0].y_0 = \begin{bmatrix} m_{0} \cr p_0 \end{bmatrix} .y0​=[m0​p0​​].
(29)

It is natural to take m0m_0m0​ as an initial condition determined outside the model.

The mathematics seems to tell us that p0p_0p0​ must also be determined outside the model, even though it is something that we actually wanted to be determined by the model.

(As usual, we should listen when mathematics talks to us.)

For now, let’s just proceed mechanically on faith.

Compute the eigenvector decomposition

H=QΛQ−1H = Q \Lambda Q^{-1}H=QΛQ−1
(30)

where Λ\LambdaΛ is a diagonal matrix of eigenvalues and the columns of QQQ are eigenvectors corresponding to those eigenvalues.

It turns out that

Λ=[Rℓ−100Ru−1]\Lambda = \begin{bmatrix} {R_\ell}^{-1} & 0 \cr 0 & {R_u}^{-1} \end{bmatrix}Λ=[Rℓ​−10​0Ru​−1​]
(31)

where RℓR_\ellRℓ​ and RuR_uRu​ are the lower and higher steady-state rates of return on currency that we computed above.

Λ, Q = np.linalg.eig(H)
print('Λ = \n', Λ)
print('Q = \n', Q)
R_l = 1 / Λ[0]
R_u = 1 / Λ[1]

print(f'R_l = {R_l:.4f}')
print(f'R_u = {R_u:.4f}')

Partition QQQ as

Q=[Q11Q12Q21Q22]Q =\begin{bmatrix} Q_{11} & Q_{12} \cr Q_{21} & Q_{22} \end{bmatrix}Q=[Q11​Q21​​Q12​Q22​​]
(32)

Below we shall verify the following claims:

Claims: If we set

p0=p‾0≡Q21Q11−1m0,p_0 = \overline p_0 \equiv Q_{21} Q_{11}^{-1} m_{0} ,p0​=p​0​≡Q21​Q11−1​m0​,
(33)

it turns out that

pt+1pt=Ru−1,t≥0\frac{p_{t+1}}{p_t} = {R_u}^{-1}, \quad t \geq 0pt​pt+1​​=Ru​−1,t≥0
(34)

However, if we set

p0>pˉ0p_0 > \bar p_0p0​>pˉ​0​
(35)

then

lim⁡t→+∞pt+1pt=Rℓ−1.\lim_{t\rightarrow + \infty} \frac{p_{t+1}}{p_t} = {R_\ell}^{-1}.t→+∞lim​pt​pt+1​​=Rℓ​−1.
(36)

Let’s verify these claims step by step.

Note that

Ht=QΛtQ−1H^t = Q \Lambda^t Q^{-1}Ht=QΛtQ−1
(37)

so that

yt=QΛtQ−1y0y_t = Q \Lambda^t Q^{-1} y_0yt​=QΛtQ−1y0​
(38)
def iterate_H(y_0, H, num_steps):
    Λ, Q = np.linalg.eig(H)
    Q_inv = np.linalg.inv(Q)
    y = np.stack(
        [Q @ np.diag(Λ**t) @ Q_inv @ y_0 for t in range(num_steps)], 1)
    
    return y

For almost all initial vectors y0y_0y0​, the gross rate of inflation pt+1pt\frac{p_{t+1}}{p_t}pt​pt+1​​ eventually converges to the larger eigenvalue Rℓ−1{R_\ell}^{-1}Rℓ​−1.

The only way to avoid this outcome is for p0p_0p0​ to take the specific value described by (33).

To understand this situation, we use the following transformation

yt∗=Q−1yt.y^*_t = Q^{-1} y_t .yt∗​=Q−1yt​.
(39)

Dynamics of yt∗y^*_tyt∗​ are evidently governed by

yt+1∗=Λtyt∗.y^*_{t+1} = \Lambda^t y^*_t .yt+1∗​=Λtyt∗​.
(40)

This equation represents the dynamics of our system in a way that lets us isolate the force that causes gross inflation to converge to the inverse of the lower steady-state rate of inflation RℓR_\ellRℓ​ that we discovered earlier.

Staring at equation (40) indicates that unless

y0∗=[y1,0∗0]y^*_0 = \begin{bmatrix} y^*_{1,0} \cr 0 \end{bmatrix}y0∗​=[y1,0∗​0​]
(41)

the path of yt∗y^*_tyt∗​, and therefore the paths of both mtm_tmt​ and ptp_tpt​ given by yt=Qyt∗y_t = Q y^*_tyt​=Qyt∗​ will eventually grow at gross rates Rℓ−1{R_\ell}^{-1}Rℓ​−1 as t→+∞t \rightarrow +\inftyt→+∞.

Equation (41) also leads us to conclude that there is a unique setting for the initial vector y0y_0y0​ for which both components forever grow at the lower rate Ru−1{R_u}^{-1}Ru​−1.

For this to occur, the required setting of y0y_0y0​ must evidently have the property that

Q−1y0=y0∗=[y1,0∗0].Q^{-1} y_0 = y^*_0 = \begin{bmatrix} y^*_{1,0} \cr 0 \end{bmatrix} .Q−1y0​=y0∗​=[y1,0∗​0​].
(42)

But note that since y0=[m0p0]y_0 = \begin{bmatrix} m_0 \cr p_0 \end{bmatrix}y0​=[m0​p0​​] and m0m_0m0​ is given to us an initial condition, p0p_0p0​ has to do all the adjusting to satisfy this equation.

Sometimes this situation is described informally by saying that while m0m_0m0​ is truly a state variable, p0p_0p0​ is a jump variable that must adjust at t=0t=0t=0 in order to satisfy the equation.

Thus, in a nutshell the unique value of the vector y0y_0y0​ for which the paths of yty_tyt​ don’t eventually grow at rate Rℓ−1{R_\ell}^{-1}Rℓ​−1 requires setting the second component of y0∗y^*_0y0∗​ equal to zero.

The component p0p_0p0​ of the initial vector y0=[m0p0]y_0 = \begin{bmatrix} m_0 \cr p_0 \end{bmatrix}y0​=[m0​p0​​] must evidently satisfy

Q{2}y0=0Q^{\{2\}} y_0 =0Q{2}y0​=0
(43)

where Q{2}Q^{\{2\}}Q{2} denotes the second row of Q−1Q^{-1}Q−1, a restriction that is equivalent to

Q21m0+Q22p0=0Q^{21} m_0 + Q^{22} p_0 = 0Q21m0​+Q22p0​=0
(44)

where QijQ^{ij}Qij denotes the (i,j)(i,j)(i,j) component of Q−1Q^{-1}Q−1.

Solving this equation for p0p_0p0​, we find

p0=−(Q22)−1Q21m0.p_0 = - (Q^{22})^{-1} Q^{21} m_0.p0​=−(Q22)−1Q21m0​.
(45)

23.7.1More convenient formula¶

We can get the equivalent but perhaps more convenient formula (33) for p0p_0p0​ that is cast in terms of components of QQQ instead of components of Q−1Q^{-1}Q−1.

To get this formula, first note that because (Q21 Q22)(Q^{21}\ Q^{22})(Q21 Q22) is the second row of the inverse of QQQ and because Q−1Q=IQ^{-1} Q = IQ−1Q=I, it follows that

[Q21Q22][Q11Q21]=0\begin{bmatrix} Q^{21} & Q^{22} \end{bmatrix} \begin{bmatrix} Q_{11}\cr Q_{21} \end{bmatrix} = 0[Q21​Q22​][Q11​Q21​​]=0
(46)

which implies that

Q21Q11+Q22Q21=0.Q^{21} Q_{11} + Q^{22} Q_{21} = 0.Q21Q11​+Q22Q21​=0.
(47)

Therefore,

−(Q22)−1Q21=Q21Q11−1.-(Q^{22})^{-1} Q^{21} = Q_{21} Q^{-1}_{11}.−(Q22)−1Q21=Q21​Q11−1​.
(48)

So we can write

p0=Q21Q11−1m0.p_0 = Q_{21} Q_{11}^{-1} m_0 .p0​=Q21​Q11−1​m0​.
(49)

which is our formula (33).

p0_bar = (Q[1, 0]/Q[0, 0]) * msm.M0

print(f'p0_bar = {p0_bar:.4f}')

It can be verified that this formula replicates itself over time in the sense that

pt=Q21Q11−1mt.p_t = Q_{21} Q^{-1}_{11} m_t.pt​=Q21​Q11−1​mt​.
(50)

Now let’s visualize the dynamics of mtm_tmt​, ptp_tpt​, and RtR_tRt​ starting from different p0p_0p0​ values to verify our claims above.

We create a function draw_iterations to generate the plot

Notebook Cell
def draw_iterations(p0s, model, line_params, num_steps):

    fig, axes = plt.subplots(3, 1, figsize=(8, 10), sharex=True)
    
    # Pre-compute time steps
    time_steps = np.arange(num_steps) 
    
    # Plot the first two y-axes in log scale
    for ax in axes[:2]:
        ax.set_yscale('log')

    # Iterate over p_0s and calculate a series of y_t
    for p0 in p0s:
        y0 = np.array([msm.M0, p0])
        y_series = iterate_H(y0, H, num_steps)
        M, P = y_series[0, :], y_series[1, :]

        # Plot R_t against time
        axes[0].plot(time_steps, M, **line_params)

        # Plot b_t against time
        axes[1].plot(time_steps, P, **line_params)
        
        # Calculate R_t
        R = np.insert(P[:-1] / P[1:], 0, np.nan)
        axes[2].plot(time_steps, R, **line_params)
        
    # Add line and text annotations to the subgraph 
    annotate_graph(axes[2], model, num_steps)
    
    # Draw labels
    axes[0].set_ylabel('$m_t$')
    axes[1].set_ylabel('$p_t$')
    axes[2].set_ylabel('$R_t$')
    axes[2].set_xlabel('timestep')
    
    # Enforce integar axis label
    axes[2].xaxis.set_major_locator(MaxNLocator(integer=True))

    plt.tight_layout()
    plt.show()
p0s = [p0_bar, 2.34, 2.5, 3, 4, 7, 30, 100_000]

draw_iterations(p0s, msm, line_params, num_steps=20)

Please notice that for mtm_tmt​ and ptp_tpt​, we have used log scales for the coordinate (i.e., vertical) axes.

Using log scales allows us to spot distinct constant limiting gross rates of growth Ru−1{R_u}^{-1}Ru​−1 and Rℓ−1{R_\ell}^{-1}Rℓ​−1 by eye.

23.8Peculiar stationary outcomes¶

As promised at the start of this lecture, we have encountered these concepts from macroeconomics:

  • an inflation tax that a government gathers by printing paper or electronic money

  • a dynamic Laffer curve in the inflation tax rate that has two stationary equilibria

Staring at the paths of rates of return on the price level in figure Fig. 2 and price levels in Fig. 3 show indicate that almost all paths converge to the higher inflation tax rate displayed in the stationary state Laffer curve displayed in figure Fig. 1.

Thus, we have indeed discovered what we earlier called “perverse” dynamics under rational expectations in which the system converges to the higher of two possible stationary inflation tax rates.

Those dynamics are “perverse” not only in the sense that they imply that the monetary and fiscal authorities that have chosen to finance government expenditures eventually impose a higher inflation tax than required to finance government expenditures, but because of the following “counterintuitive” situation that we can deduce by staring at the stationary state Laffer curve displayed in figure Fig. 1:

  • the figure indicates that inflation can be reduced by running higher government deficits, i.e., by raising more resources through printing money.

Note

The same qualitative outcomes prevail in this lecture Inflation Rate Laffer Curves that studies a nonlinear version of the model in this lecture.

23.9Equilibrium selection¶

We have discovered that as a model of price level paths or model is incomplete because there is a continuum of “equilibrium” paths for {mt+1,pt}t=0∞\{m_{t+1}, p_t\}_{t=0}^\infty{mt+1​,pt​}t=0∞​ that are consistent with the demand for real balances always equaling the supply.

Through application of our computational methods 1 and 2, we have learned that this continuum can be indexed by choice of one of two scalars:

  • for computational method 1, R0R_0R0​

  • for computational method 2, p0p_0p0​

To apply our model, we have somehow to complete it by selecting an equilibrium path from among the continuum of possible paths.

We discovered that

  • all but one of the equilibrium paths converge to limits in which the higher of two possible stationary inflation tax prevails

  • there is a unique equilibrium path associated with “plausible” statements about how reductions in government deficits affect a stationary inflation rate

On grounds of plausibility, we recommend following many macroeconomists in selecting the unique equilibrium that converges to the lower stationary inflation tax rate.

As we shall see, we shall accept this recommendation in lecture Some Unpleasant Monetarist Arithmetic.

In lecture, Laffer Curves with Adaptive Expectations, we shall explore how Bruno & Fischer (1990) and others justified this in other ways.

References¶
  1. Bruno, M., & Fischer, S. (1990). Seigniorage, operating rules, and the high inflation trap. The Quarterly Journal of Economics, 105(2), 353–374.
